newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican banks seek bankruptcy of Taesa - report.
newsitem.headline: Mexican banks seek bankruptcy of Taesa - report.

text.p: Two Mexican banks have sought the liquidation of Taesa, a major Mexican airline that owes at least $100 million, El Economista reported on Wednesday.

The newspaper said Bancomer, Mexico's second largest bank, filed a petition in a Mexico City court for Taesa to be declared bankrupt, saying the airline had lost more than two-thirds of its share capital and was unable to meet its debt obligations.
A Bancomer spokesman said he was unable to confirm the move against Taesa. A spokesman at Taesa was not immediately available for comment.
El Economista said Banco Union, the bank intervened by the Mexican government, had also previously sought the liquidation of Taesa. It said Taesa owed some $100 million to Banco Union.

The newspaper said Taesa controlled some 30 percent of Mexican commercial air traffic during the 1988-1994 administration of ex-President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. All top Mexican airlines were clobbered by the devaluation of the peso in December 1994.
